0.18.text: So there's an early election on. Agh!

2.90.text:
Today I'm going to Birmingham to talk to Jess
Phillips.

5.88.text:
Now, Jess Phillips, you know she has her strong
admirers,

9.20.text:
she has her detractors but if we don't keep
seats like that

13.14.text: we're in a bit of a mess.

14.88.text: So I want to find out, how is it in Birmingham?

18.31.text: What's the mood on the ground?

19.55.text: And what's the future for Labour?

21.33.text:
Hiya! Hey everyone, how are you doing? You
alright?

35.22.text: That side of the road you're with John.

37.00.text: John, you're on that side of the road.

44.08.text:
In some of the polling at the moment, obviously
the Tories have a whopping big lead.

49.00.text: But Labour's vote at the moment is kind of...

51.20.text: They're on about what they were on last time.

55.33.text:
Yes, but Tory voters are much more likely
to be, you know,

60.77.text: they'll vote around. They'll vote around.

64.77.text: Yeah, they like to be wooed.

67.40.text:
Whereas people who vote Labour are, I think,
a lot more tribal

73.60.text:
and I think people will vote for what they
know.

76.18.text:
Also, because people don't really want this
election, so ...

78.93.text:
Is that coming up? Are people on the doorstep
going ...?

80.79.text:
Oh god! All the time! That woman from Bristol
in that famous film.

84.89.text:
Yeah, they're like: 'Get on with your job,
love. You've only just started.'

89.20.text:
I'm like: 'Believe you me, I did not want
this election.

93.18.text:
A lot of people think all people want to talk
about

96.27.text: That's the narrative of the press at the moment.

97.58.text: Not at all. Not at all.

98.58.text:
So people aren't going: 'I'm a leaver. I'm
a remainer.

102.50.text: Not at all. Not at all.

105.56.text:
People talk to me genuinely more about Gogglebox
than they do about Brexit.

109.60.text: Ha ha! It's a big issue.

112.72.text:
This is Habib, who is a Yardley campaigning
legend.

117.70.text:
I used to have a shoe shop up on the road
so they used to all come in.

121.80.text: That's a great way of getting to know people.

126.60.text:
If someone forgets their phone number he goes:
'It's alright.'

127.86.text:
And he goes through his phone and gets the
phone number.

132.96.text:
If I was going to ask you for the top three
issues in this constituency,

136.56.text: what do you reckon they are?

139.62.text:
The single biggest issue is always pavement
politics.

142.34.text: It is stuff about the grass verges, the bins.

145.84.text:
Do people complain about, I've noticed a lot
of this on the doorstep,

147.96.text:
other people's gardens? They get really angry
about it.

151.01.text: Oh my god, yeah! Other people's gardens, yeah.

153.38.text: Big trees in other people's gardens.

156.59.text: So I'd put all of that into one category.

162.36.text: And then I would say housing.

166.18.text: The fact that people can't afford to buy houses

168.18.text:
and people are inappropriately housed in my
constituency is really bad.

174.82.text: Have you had any Lib Dems?

176.54.text:
No, not yet. I haven't really had anyone yet
to be honest.

179.84.text: Well, today yeah but not right now.

183.07.text:
No, we're talking about now. Have you got
anyone voting for anyone yet?

187.49.text: Maybe you need to ask the other team.

191.06.text:
Did you watch Theresa May on the One Show
the other day?

193.38.text:
I didn't. I've only seen the really cringey
shoe thing.

196.92.text:
In a lift where she said a woman said to her
she got involved

199.76.text: in politics because of Theresa May's shoes?

201.32.text: I mean, give me actual strength.

204.66.text:
It is true that polling and anecdotal stuff
backs it up,

208.84.text: a lot of people seem to quite like her,

211.38.text:
which for people like me and you is a bit
odd, maybe.

214.80.text:
Why? Come on, what do you think it is? Why
is she (so popular)?

217.68.text:
I think that the Tories have essentially created
a sense

221.50.text: of complete instability in the country,

223.39.text:
which is ironic considering what their lovely
catchphrases are.

228.08.text: She is sort of like a phoenix from the ashes

230.26.text: which she lit the paper on.

237.54.text: and they promote that sense of chaos

239.13.text:
but claim they're the only thing that can
stabilise

241.02.text: the chaos that they themselves have caused.

243.93.text: It is clever. It's clever if you can do it.

246.11.text:
If you have the money and the PR to do it
and if you have

248.84.text:
essentially a lightning rod, which they feel
they have in Jeremy Corbyn,

253.61.text:
they can charge themselves up like the power
of Greyskull.

260.47.text: But people just want a simpler life.

263.88.text:
This is my favourite named street in Yardley:
Fast Pits Road.

269.84.text: I don't know why I'm laughing so loud.

277.36.text: So you've been an MP now for two years.

278.90.text:
It's been a very quiet, uneventful period
in British history.

281.30.text: What are you most proud of?

282.76.text:
I am most proud of raising the profile of
domestic violence victims,

287.76.text: and for actually changing the law so that no perpetrator

293.76.text: of domestic violence will ever be allowed

295.42.text: to question their victim in a family court.

298.81.text:
I am also proud, the most proud, I think actually
was to stand

305.56.text: with the families of the Birmingham pub bombings

308.65.text: and get them the legal aid that they deserved

310.44.text:
because it was like a proper David and Goliath
story.

313.50.text:
What's been the worst thing about being an
MP?

315.48.text: Oh god! I don't like being away from my family

318.02.text: and, whilst I'm no fan of the snap election,

320.31.text:
the pleasure of waking up in my own bed every
day

326.02.text:
It's very, very difficult for people with
young families, I think,

329.36.text: to be members of parliament. So, that is difficult.

332.74.text:
And, you know, we suffered a terrible, terrible
loss when Jo [Cox] was killed

336.83.text:
and feeling like you're in a class of people
who is now hunted –

342.91.text:
and for journalists it's the same actually,
I think,

346.03.text: it's a similar thing – isn't the best.

351.89.text:
All I'm trying to do, genuinely and I know
it sounds trite and rubbish,

355.70.text: is trying to like make things better for people

358.28.text: and then I became a target because of that.

360.84.text:
I mean, there's some people, really, like
much worse than me.

365.43.text:
Ha ha! Some really, genuinely, malevolent
people out there.

369.00.text:
Yeah, why me? I mean, I'm just like trying
to help Betty with her tree

373.32.text:
and the flats at the back of her house and
like, you know,

376.78.text:
sort out this youth centre just over the road,
which we managed to save

380.74.text:
and people want to kill me because of it.
Weird.

388.34.text: If Labour is a family, which I think it is,

390.86.text:
is Labour going to stay together after whatever
happens?

395.82.text:
Yeah, I mean, I think so because I think that
that tribal tendency

398.95.text: is really hard to shake, isn't it?

400.89.text: I remember once that I tried not to vote Labour

402.51.text:
and my hand was like a Ouija Board. I couldn't
not do it.

407.25.text: I think it will come back together

408.34.text:
but like when you have a falling out with
your family,

412.00.text:
which I do all the time, everybody has to
give a little bit.

416.37.text:
I think that the trouble is that there's certain
factions

422.19.text: that will not give an inch from both sides.

426.38.text:
That has got to stop because we're going to
be ...

429.26.text:
I hope that we're going to get like, you know
that bit

431.53.text:
in between Christmas and New Year that everybody
really likes

433.55.text:
because you don't have to go and do anything,
there's no no obligations.

436.54.text:
I hope that after the election, when everyone's
so tired

439.11.text:
and so stuffed full of turkey, that we're
going to sit around together

442.90.text:
and watch a crap film that we've all seen
before and feel a bit better.

446.79.text: Then there's the dirty washing up.

448.23.text: Someone's going to have to clean that up.

449.43.text: Yeah, that'll be the Labour women.

452.09.text:
The Labour women, they always clean up the
mess.

454.86.text: So I'm an opinion writer. I'm an activist.

456.81.text: I don't pretend to be neutral or objective.

458.96.text:
I want Labour to do well in this election
and what I found from today

463.40.text: is there is some ground for some optimism.

465.92.text:
This is so hard. All the odds are stacked
against Labour,

468.92.text: there's no point in pretending otherwise.

470.22.text:
But, it does show, if you get people out knocking
on doors and campaigning

473.72.text: it's the only way to turn things around.

475.38.text: So, I thought that was interesting and I want to see what you think.

481.02.text: A lot of you won't agree with me. Good.

482.52.text: I want to hear from you.

484.16.text: Subscribe. I'll see you next time.
